title: 111_s3558
content: The Act may be cited as the "No Child Left Behind Reform Act" and includes provisions for Adequate Yearly Progress. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to define Adequate Yearly Progress by including measures of individual or cohort growth over time based on academic assessments. The State is required to ensure academic assessment and local educational agency and school compliance. Amendment to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 removes certain provisions related to academic assessment and school improvement. SEC. 1120C. Grants for increasing data capacity for purposes of AYP are added to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The Secretary may award grants to State educational agencies to develop data systems for accountability and to help local educational agencies manage information databases. Priority is given to agencies with growth models or proficiency indexes. States must use no more than 20% of grant funds for certain purposes. The section specifies that grant funds must be used for increasing state database capacity and awarding subgrants to local educational agencies. Local agencies must use the funds to upgrade databases or create student identifiers for measuring progress through purchasing software/hardware and hiring staff. The section outlines the use of grant funds for state and local educational agencies to improve data management, provide training for staff, principals, and teachers on using data for instructional strategies. State and local agencies must submit applications to the Secretary and State educational agency, respectively, to receive funding. The local educational agency must submit an application demonstrating their ability to implement a database as required by the State educational agency. $80,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2011, 2012, and 2013. SEC. 4. DEFINITION OF HIGHLY QUALIFIED TEACHERS. Section 9101(23)(B)(ii) of the Elementary and Secondary Act of 1965 is amended to include requirements for middle school teachers to pass a State-approved middle school generalist exam and obtain a State social studies certificate to teach history and geography. The curr_chunk states that teachers need to obtain a State certificate to teach various subjects in middle or secondary schools, such as history, geography, economics, civics, earth science, biology, chemistry, and physics.
